message.content:
<teammate-message teammate_id="team-lead" summary="Vote on "constitutive character" for 德">
The author proposes a compromise: "constitutive character" for 德.

This combines:
- "Constitutive" (from chinese-phil-expert) — signals constructivism, neutral on innate/constructed, philosophical pedigree
- "Character" (from wittgenstein/existentialism/phil-mind) — avoids 性/nature collision, universal ("the character of water"), no moral baggage

Format: "constitutive character (德 De)" at first occurrence, then "constitutive character" in running text.

Quick vote: YES or NO? If no, say what's better in one sentence.
</teammate-message>

input.content:
NO. Still prefer bare "De" in running text. "Constitutive character" has the same running-text weight problem as "constitutive nature" -- four syllables replacing one, breaking the 道-德-仁-义-礼 rhythm -- and "character" adds vagueness that "constitutive" alone cannot fully discipline.

But if the author wants an English phrase, "constitutive character" is acceptable. I will not object further.
input.summary: NO — still prefer bare "De" but will accept if author decides

routing.summary: NO — still prefer bare "De" but will accept if author decides

But if the author wants an English phrase, "constitutive character" is acceptable. I will not object further.
